Taking bible verses out of context has become something many Christians have learned to avoid, so they believe that taking the verse in the context of the story is valid.


This is an incorrect assumption.


Because the Bible does not contradict itself, not a single verse will contradict the Bible. If a verse's only bounds are its story, and the conclusion/meaning of the story that is jumped to contradicts the Bible, it is not the true meaning of the story (Not that the decided meaning is immediately completely invalid, but it has parts that were assumed incorrectly, and need to be fixed). For example,


Matthew 21:18-22 - stuff - Immediately the tree withered. - stuff - "When the disciples saw this, they were amazed. “How did the fig tree wither so quickly?” they asked." 
 

"Okay, the tree was withered in a second. Very cool."


Mark 11:12-14 and 20-25 says Jesus cursed the fig tree and they saw it withered the next morning.


"Hey, didn't I decide the fig tree was cursed and withered immediately? 503 error oh well, guess that other verse doesn't count." 


No. Upon closer inspection of these two different verses, seemingly different stories, we find that Matthew omits the exact time that went by and just focused on that it was very fast, and Mark says the exact time that has passed. 


This does not mean that you can pretend that the bible is something it is not or something you personally believe. For example, if I were to say "No, hell doesn't exist because God is loving" and you say the reason Hell exists when God is loving (though I'm not going to go into it right now), and I say "Well, there's more verses that say God is loving, so I guess that's wrong" I would be completely incorrect. Just like verses cannot contradict the bible, the bible cannot contradict verses.

Incorrect. Because context determines meanings in many instances. For example "whoever eats and drinks unworthily eats and drinks condemnation upon himself". Without the broader context that this is in a passage about communion, it appears as if it's talking about your diet, which is not what it's talking about at all.

The other thing is, and everyone here is going to kill me for this but it needs to be said: the idea that this book called "the bible" is completely accurate and 100% true is just made up bullshit. Tell me in the bible itself where it says to believe the bible. You won't, because it didn't even exist until the catholic church decided on a universal canon in 382 AD. Prior to that the authenticity of books was debated and the "writings" of great people were not seen on the same level as God (even though most seem to elevate them above him today) and this is a historical fact. This is the real reason why they got a lot of inspiration from the apocrypha and books like Enoch despite also contradicting them when necessary; however this was also true for the books in the jewish canon, which our protestant old testament is copied from. Sorry, but even in forgeries like Timothy the most you'll get is vague references to "scripture" which is never defined. The beginning of John is pretty clear what, or rather *who* "the word" is and it is *not* identified as the bible which wouldn't even exist for another 300 years. There are plenty of contradictions in the bible between different authors who had different ideas, and also from scribes inserting their agendas into the text, either on purpose or by mistakenly copying a note from the margin of the previous copy into it (the margins were also used for parts of the text a scribe had originally glossed over, which made them very easy to confuse). There are many variant readings, most famously the woman in adultery, and this is undeniable. "The Bible" as the word and authority rather than Jesus was a tool made up by the catholic church to control people, and is still used by satan to confuse people and keep them from the extremely simple but great message.

I’m a relatively new convert to Christianity, but I’m really getting into the Bible - it’s blowing my mind how rich, complex, nuanced, and perfect it is. 

It’s a narrative, it’s literature, it’s a historical record, it’s a book of wisdom and ancient philosophy, it’s an anthology, and it’s the word of God. 

Here’s my beginners take on the bible: 

It’s the living word of God. It’s both literally true, and purely metaphorical- because it’s bigger than the confines of human language. It is both contradictory, and completely cohesive. It’s bigger than the dialectical idea that it must be one or the other. 

Just like how Jesus taught in parables so that those with ears can hear, the whole bible is written in a way that you can spend 100 lifetimes devoted to nothing but bible study, and no human could ever fully ‘get it’. 

It contains all the messages God will ever need to send you- sometimes with the context of the narrative, sometimes without that narrative.

The Living Word of God transcends any words we use to describe it. It is perfect, and flawed, and whether you see it as divine or a hoax, or complete or contradictory, depends more on your faith than anything to do with the bible itself. 

If you believe, and if you humble yourself before God, then the bible will become for you the full and complete message God needs you to hear. 

If you doubt, and if you lean on your own understanding to make sense of God’s word, then it won’t amount to much for you because you lack ears to hear.

body: Not a Protestant, my friend. I loath the doctrines of the tv preachers, who are not able to be accurately described as Christians. But the reason I did not even attempt to use the Bible to prove the Bible is because it always leads to circular logic and special pleading, which is the dilemma of the *sola scriptura* doctrine. You are absolutely correct when you say that the Bible doesn’t claim that it is the sole authority and that it doesn’t specify what is and is not cannon. That is precisely why there is a little thing called *THE CHURCH*. Jesus Christ Himself says within Matthew 16:18 that He shall build a Church and that “the gates of hell shall not prevail against it.” He says also in Matthew 28:20 that He will be with us “even to the end of the age,” and that He will send the Helper unto us, Who is the Holy Spirit, in John 16:7. Therefore, when we have the testimony of the early Christians, such as St. Ignatius, St. Clement, and St. Polycarp, who themselves were students of Apostles and Disciples of Christ such as St. John and St, Peter, we can safely conclude that what they say is correct based upon the Words of Christ Himself. Furthermore, it is these very individuals who testify of and appeal authoritatively to the books which you cite as “forgeries”. That is precisely how we know the whole of the New Testament to be scripture and how we know who wrote them: not by using the books to prove themselves, but learning from those led by the Holy Spirit, upholding their veracity for our sakes as their spiritual descendants. As for the books you claim teach “works salvation,” this simply results from a misunderstanding which arises from a false dichotomy between faith and works, which are in fact inseparable. As for John 1 itself, I honestly don’t see where this dilemma arises that the Bible cannot be the Word of God because Jesus is the Word of God. They are *both* correctly referred to as the Word of God. Jesus is the Word, the divine *Logos*, because He proclaims the Gospel of Salvation which comes from the Father through Him: He is the Gospel. The Bible is the Word of God because it is the full, wholly true, and wholly inspired revelation of Jesus Christ, the Son of God, Who is fully God and fully man, unto mankind by the Holy Spirit and God the Father as far as human language is able to properly describe it. The Bible contains the only Words spoken from the mouth of God Himself, and therefore is properly called the Word of God.

It’s a narrative, it’s literature, it’s a historical record, it’s a book of wisdom and ancient philosophy, it’s an anthology, and it’s the word of God.

It’s the living word of God. It’s both literally true, and purely metaphorical- because it’s bigger than the confines of human language. It is both contradictory, and completely cohesive. It’s bigger than the dialectical idea that it must be one or the other.

The Living Word of God transcends any words we use to describe it. It is perfect, and flawed, and whether you see it as divine or a hoax, or complete or contradictory, depends more on your faith than anything to do with the bible itself. 

If you believe, and if you humble yourself before God, then the bible will become for you the full and complete message God needs you to hear. 

If you doubt, and if you lean on your own understanding to make sense of God’s word, then it won’t amount to much for you because you lack ears to hear.

I’m a relatively new convert to Christianity, but I’m really getting into the Bible - it’s blowing my mind how rich, complex, nuanced, and perfect it is. 

It’s a narrative, it’s literature, it’s a historical record, it’s a book of wisdom and ancient philosophy, it’s an anthology, and it’s the word of God. 

Here’s my beginners take on the bible: 

It’s the living word of God. It’s both literally true, and purely metaphorical- because it’s bigger than the confines of human language. It is both contradictory, and completely cohesive. It’s bigger than the dialectical idea that it must be one or the other. 

Just like how Jesus taught in parables so that those with ears can hear, the whole bible is written in a way that you can spend 100 lifetimes devoted to nothing but bible study, and no human could ever fully ‘get it’. 

It contains all the messages God will ever need to send you- sometimes with the context of the narrative, sometimes without that narrative.

The Living Word of God transcends any words we use to describe it. It is perfect, and flawed, and whether you see it as divine or a hoax, or complete or contradictory, depends more on your faith than anything to do with the bible itself. 

If you believe, and if you humble yourself before God, then the bible will become for you the full and complete message God needs you to hear. 

If you doubt, and if you lean on your own understanding to make sense of God’s word, then it won’t amount to much for you because you lack ears to hear.

> That is precisely why there is a little thing called *THE CHURCH*. Jesus Christ Himself says within Matthew 16:18 that He shall build a Church and that “the gates of hell shall not prevail against it.”

Which church? The one that didn't even exist until after they were all dead already? Which denomination? They don't all have the same canons, and they had even more differing ones prior to 382. I imagine Peter's response was something like "what the fuck is a church?!". It actually means *assembly* which is the ministry as a whole, and it's also quite possibly an interpolation added by catholics to support the papacy. It does interrupt the text but not dramatically, so it could be original, the part that seems off to me is "I will give you the keys of the kingdom of heaven. Whatever you bind on earth will be bound in heaven, and whatever you loose on earth will be loosed in heaven". That's pretty much making Peter another god, which definitely isn't supported anywhere else. There could be a language barrier or misinterpretation here but either way it's dubious in its current form and contradicts other teachings.

> He says also in Matthew 28:20 that He will be with us “even to the end of the age,” and that He will send the Helper unto us, Who is the Holy Spirit, in John 16:7.

If anything that is against the church crap and in support of his teachings of having ears to hear and eyes to see. Why would the Holy Spirit need to indwell in believers if they're just supposed to listen to the church?

> Therefore, when we have the testimony of the early Christians, such as St. Ignatius, St. Clement, and St. Polycarp, who themselves were students of Apostles and Disciples of Christ such as St. John and St, Peter, we can safely conclude that what they say is correct based upon the Words of Christ Himself. Furthermore, it is these very individuals who testify of and appeal authoritatively to the books which you cite as “forgeries”.

I'm skeptical of all these early church saints because they often contradict Jesus and some of them seem like they had an agenda or were agents of the Roman empire. Not even the disciples who had physically been with Jesus for 3 years could agree on major issues, let alone them. Also calling people "saint" is pretty much idolatry and judging in place of God. I'm not aware of anyone in the bible ever addressing people with that title, not even in later forgeries like the pastoral epistles.

> That is precisely how we know the whole of the New Testament to be scripture and how we know who wrote them: not by using the books to prove themselves, but learning from those led by the Holy Spirit, upholding their veracity for our sakes as their spiritual descendants.

Don't you need your own discernment to determine who was led by the Holy Spirit in the first place? In the gospels and authentic letters discernment is not encouraged only for "special" people, in fact the people, including the "perfect" disciples, are repeatedly rebuked for *not* doing so as if it should go without saying.

> As for the books you claim teach “works salvation,” this simply results from a misunderstanding which arises from a false dichotomy between faith and works, which are in fact inseparable. James 2:18 even says something to this effect when he writes, “But someone will say, ‘You have faith, and I have works.’ Show me your faith without your works, and I will show you my faith by my works.” Revelation 20:12 also speaks of the role which works have in our salvation when the Apostle John (the same John who wrote John 1:1) describes people being judged by their works before God during the Last Judgement.

The gospels and Paul's actual letters are both extremely clear that it is NOT works. They encourage good works and seem to expect that believers will *desire* to do so, but are adamant that faith alone is what does it. The parable of the pharisee and the tax collector makes no sense otherwise, nor do many stories in the gospels. Also James 2:14 is clear that works *save* a person, so saying it's talking about evidence and good fruit is just twisting it. It even quotes against Paul's use of Abraham's faith being counted as righteousness, with an odd interpretation of Abraham being saved by his about-to-sacrifice Isaac. The epistle of "James" is also pseudographical. Also the John who wrote Revelation was likely NOT the same John as the one who wrote the gospel of John and maybe the 3 letters of John, there is some complaints from early churches that a false teacher had forged it and that John had denounced him, and the wildly different writing styles would seem to agree. Not saying this is what happened but it's a possibility, there's some seemingly contradictory messages in Revelation but it's also extremely difficult to interpret, I give it a 50/50 chance of being authentic. As for Revelation 20:12, it also speaks of the book of life of people who were exempt from this judgement, which would agree with the rest of the NT that judgement and law is for non-believers, not believers (and by believers I mean actual followers).

> As for John 1 itself, I honestly don’t see where this dilemma arises that the Bible cannot be the Word of God because Jesus is the Word of God. They are both correctly referred to as the Word of God. Jesus is the Word, the divine Logos, because He proclaims the Gospel of Salvation which comes from the Father through Him: He is the Gospel. The Bible is the Word of God because it is the full, wholly true, and wholly inspired revelation of Jesus Christ, the Son of God, Who is fully God and fully man, unto mankind by the Holy Spirit and God the Father as far as human language is able to properly describe it.

This is completely false. It gives no indication of a perfect, preserved text. None. And even if it did, it doesn't say anything about the bible.

> The Bible contains the only Words spoken from the mouth of God Himself, and therefore is properly called the Word of God.

Wrong, we have all the writers of the works in Genesis, Moses, whoever wrote Job, David, Solomon, Paul, and a ton of others including forgers. It contains the words of God too but that does not make everything else the words of God. I could write something awful in a bible right now but it being placed next to God's words won't make it his words.

> Which church? The one that didn't even exist until after they were all dead already? Which denomination?

The Acts 2 Church. The Church that existed apart from any denominations. That which was preserved from Apostolic succession, which is the transferring of the Holy Spirit from one bishop or presbyter to another via the laying of hands, which is described in Acts 1:20-26 and in the “forgery” 1 Timothy 4:14 (which even if it were a forgery, it still describes the practices and beliefs of the Christians during the time in which it was written [A.D. 53-A.D. 63).

> It actually means assembly which is the ministry as a whole,

This doesn’t do anything to disprove that the Church is the Body of Christ (1 Corinthians 12, Ephesians 4:1-16) or the Light and Pillar of Truth (1 Timothy 3:15), which entails it being an organized and structured entity or assemblage. The function of the Church, moreover, is conciliar, meaning that disagreements, pressing concerns, and heresies are sorted out within councils presided over by bishops (such as James [Bishop of Jerusalem] and Peter [Bishop of Antioch and later Rome]), elders, and apostles (such as the aforementioned two) as is demonstrated in Acts 15.

> They don't all have the same canons, and they had even more differing ones prior to 382.

This really doesn’t matter much when you consider the Ecumenical Councils and the *phronema*, or mindset, of the Church. Sure, certain issues were settled at local councils in their canons or by the orders of a bishop, yet more controversial ones, such as Gnosticism, Arianism, Nestorianism, or Iconoclasm, were eventually dealt with in the Ecumenical councils, which were codified by prayer, fasting, and studying scripture and the general teachings of the preceding fathers. That is also how the complete canon of the Bible came to be.

> "I will give you the keys of the kingdom of heaven. Whatever you bind on earth will be bound in heaven, and whatever you loose on earth will be loosed in heaven". That's pretty much making Peter another god, which definitely isn't supported anywhere else.

This may be proven to be authentic because of the controversies which abounded about it during the late first millennium, and how the Western half of the Church began to interpret this as a prooftext for Papal Supremacy, while the Eastern half always held that it referred to the Apostolic authority of the clergy, conferred by the Holy Spirit, and the powers they received thereby. It does not make Peter a god, but merely again upholds the authority which the Church has because of Christ and the Holy Spirit, which Christ declares in John 20:22-23, “...**Receive ye the Holy Ghost**: Whose soever sins ye remit, they are remitted unto them; and whose soever sins ye retain, they are retained.” Not they in and of themselves, of course, but the Holy Spirit through them. 

> Why would the Holy Spirit need to indwell in believers if they're just supposed to listen to the church?

So that Christians would know what is true and proper doctrine. I do not say that authorities in the Church cannot make mistakes and even commit blasphemy. They are still human after all.  That is a principal reason why we have the Holy Spirit: so that we have “eyes to see and ears to hear”, and know who does and does not speak the truth, and reprove them if need be. Yet the purpose of the Holy Spirit is to be the Guide unto all Truth within the Church, and if the Church apostatized after the death of the last Apostle, as I reckon you assume, then Christ would be a liar and the Holy Spirit either evil or nonexistent. Moreover, to illustrate, if there were a room full of people who all disagreed with one another: Jim saying that he denies the divinity of Christ; Jill saying that she is a manifestation of Christ; and Bob saying that Christ is the Son of God, the second Person of the Trinity, and yet they all claim that a single Spirit led them to those conclusions, then the Holy Spirit would be a relativistic leader, and truth would no longer be meaningful. Therefore, that is why the councils and dogmas of the Church are so important, because they sort out these issues and proclaim what is and isn’t the Truth, from scripture *and* tradition (2 Thessalonians 2:15).

> I'm skeptical of all these early church saints because they often contradict Jesus and some of them seem like they had an agenda or were agents of the Roman empire.

Firstly, that seems unlikely since they proved what they discoursed about from Jesus and the Old Testament. Secondly, that seems honestly even more unlikely since all they endeavored to do was uphold the doctrines that they were taught from the Apostles, and were all martyred for treason against the Roman state because they refused to give up their faith and sacrifice to the gods or burn incense to the emperor.

> Not even the disciples who had physically been with Jesus for 3 years could agree on major issues, let alone them. 

That is the purpose of discourse and councils, to resolve disagreements and controversies, as in Acts 15.

> Also calling people "saint" is pretty much idolatry and judging in place of God. I'm not aware of anyone in the bible ever addressing people with that title, not even in later forgeries like the pastoral epistles.

No. “Saint” derives from the Latin word, *sanctus*, which can mean “venerable,” “divine,” “blessed,” or “holy.” In Greek, it is *agios*, meaning “holy.” The reason certain individuals are granted the appellate “saint” is to indicate the status they have achieved as exemplars and defenders of the Faith unto all of us. They are holy even as He is holy, perfect even as he is perfect (Matthew 5:48), and are par takers of the Divine nature (2 Peter 1:4). They do not *ever* take the place of God. Certain theologians in the first millennium, anticipating objections like this, endeavor to stress the nuance in Greek between the two forms of devotion evinced by the words *latreia* and *dulia*; the former being equated in English with the word, “veneration,” due to Saints, relics, and such, and the second being equated with “worship” proper, due to God alone. Further explanation would involve some deep theology which is irrelevant to the topic at hand.
